content: I hear this question all the time, and I applaud you for taking this head-on. When it comes to learning new skills — like coding — people commonly under-estimate the value of life experience, and over-estimate the negative effects associated with the aging brain. Assuming older people don’t have neurodegenerative illness, it’s generally much easier for them to develop new skills than younger people, because they have more pre-existing knowledge with which to relate new knowledge. I suspect the main reasons people think younger people are smarter is because younger people are less likely to have kids or full-time jobs, and thus have more free time to practice new skills.
